data.text: Do you worry about wild animals when cycle traveling
Do you worry about wild animals when traveling, like tiger.
No. But I'm in the UK.
data.author: Matt Mis

data.text: If I see a tiger in the UK I'd be pretty worried yea
data.author: Mark Holland

data.text: I have seen a tiger in UK. But that was in a wild animal park 😉
data.author: Jenni Kylmäkoski

data.text: Dogs are a much bigger danger than wild animals.
data.author: Peter Muhammad

data.text: There is a higher probability of being bitten by the dog!
data.author: Lukas Schepers

data.text: I rode across India, but mostly a developed part. The plan was to bike to Assam (I got sick), and there are wild tigers there and yeah, I thought about it. But if you love nature, you have to accept certain (very unlikely) possibilities.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: No wild tigers in the rural areas, unless you are travelling through any of the wild life sanctuaries/parks. Most of the major roads no sightings of tigers, except might be a few wild elephants, deers, water buffalos, mountain cattles (mostly in Arunachal & Nagaland). But, tigers most unlikely, unless, that too might be, at wee hours and one plans to camp inside a wildlife sanctuary/park 😜. Since, you mentioned, Assam and I'M from Assam, I HAD to jump in. 😄
data.author: Junaid Parvez

data.text: Jokes apart, when did you travel to India? Cycling is now getting big in the North East, you can contact SpokeHub Cycling, they will guide you about cycling in Assam, and most of NE. They organise/sponsor multiple cycling related events all over NE and they also conduct on bike tours as well. Hope, you do come to the NE. It'll be unlike anywhere than rest of India, unique cultures, different tribes and totally different food. We use very less masalas but Ghost chilly originated and grown in Assam & Nagaland. Happy Pedalling. 🚴‍♂️
data.author: Junaid Parvez

data.text: 2017, the trip ended up being from Delhi to Varanasi, where I got really sick. I wasn’t going to make it out of the country by the time my visa ended, so I had to fly home (I live in Thailand). Thinking of trying again, but this time I definitely can’t ride all the way, given the political situation in Myanmar. I’ll drop you a line if I do, thanks!
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: sure do. But, flying in would be better. Let’s hope situation in Myanmar improves. Road trip to Thailand had been a long time dream for me.

data.text: Absolutely! Well, I only worried about tigers hiking once. It’s always good to remember than many predators - like tigers or wolves - are nocturnal, so you’re gonna be fine if you cycle during the day. And if you’re in territory where there are many of them, well... I wouldn’t camp, but try to find lodging.

data.text:
In North America, Brown Bears are a slight concern. Black Bears tend to run. Mountain Lions are very shy too. South America, I think people are a little concerned about big cats there. Maybe big animals in Africa. Hippos cause some deaths. Indians have trouble with Tigers, but still only in the dozens every year (https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20191120-the-problem-of-indias-man-eating-tigers). There's a documentary about "The Real Indiana Joneses". One of them says it's the insects that get you. Malaria, Dengue.... Street dogs and crazy drivers. They cause me trouble.
The problem with India’s man-eating tigers
bbc.com
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: Frequently, although I am reassured by the fact that there have been no reports of Tiger attacks in northern England recently. Nonetheless, I still steer clear of watering holes and choose the relative safety of pubs instead, just to be safe.

data.author: Mark Pilkington

data.text: Having slept out, bivvy bag in places like, Australia, India, New Zealand, Morocco, America, Spain and several other European countries, it’s the smaller bugs that worry me. It’s never mentioned much, but ants can be a nightmare, flies, mosquitoes etc. Yes tigers worried me at night in India, and signs saying, Tigers roam these forests at night, highlighted the dangers, and made me more anxious, so I stuck to lodgings, they were dirt cheap anyway. Bears in America was similar. You need to be aware of the dangers in these countries regarding animals, however the ones that will annoy you must undoubtedly will be bugs. In Australia, my face looked like I had leprosy, due to mosquitoes, huge lumps appeared on my face, filled with pus! Ants bit me incessantly, crawling up my legs, flies buzzing round me, when I was trying to eat. I took to sleeping on benches at night in picnic area’s, a lot of the time, to get away from the creepie crawlies. Then I was warned about snakes in the grass, spiders, river gum trees that fall on you etc. There are dangers and okay I saw a bear in America, and they can smell food for miles away, but you hope that putting food away from your campsite, up a tree etc, will help. But the joy of seeing the wildlife at night, and the stars etc, makes it all worthwhile, or so I tell myself, when the truth is, I am a cheapskate. Only once been found by people, a homeless guy, whilst sleeping in a boat, on a children’s play area, I assumed this was his normal spot. Just familiarise yourself with the dangers of each country, many countries have none, only people!
data.author: John Reynolds

data.text: I’ve seen coyotes and rattlesnakes here in California but when I went fishing in Alaska they gave us plenty warnings about bear and especially moose.
data.author: Louie Garcia

And 🐑 are dangerous because they are everywhere besides the streets in Norway. So be careful when going downhill

data.text: Generally no, there are far greater dangers already mentioned by others but be sensible, if your doing The Great Divide take pepper spray and an Air Horn. In South Africa decide carefully where you go and how. Use your intelligence do your research but keep the relative dangers in proportion. In terms of harm I would use this as a descending scale of danger: vehicles, roads, man, sun, weather, water quality, insects, dogs, lack of self care, not listening to your body, poor nutrition, pushing to a schedule, living by the numbers rather than the feeling, lack of rest, lack of bike care,,,,,, animals.
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: excellent list
data.author: Rich Oberleitner

data.text: I am increasingly worried about wolves in the Jura and Valais. They have been reintroduced. I have been barked at by aggressive dogs enough, to worry about wolves.

data.text: The last two dangerous meetings and also crashes were bacause of a lizzard and a frog. No one wants to kill those small cuties. So I had to stop that hard that I turned into a catapult. All my bags were flying over the frog but not onto. The lizzard before had less luck. She ran so fast towards me that I changed immediately the direction. She did the same and ran back directly under my tire and I rolled over her. I was so sad that I was not able to go on by bike for five days 😥... 🦎

data.text: I can see that since they may be attracted to any food you have. Most of the ones near us live in suburban green spaces along bayous and creeks. They only get to be about 40-50 lbs at most. They typically hunt rabbits and squirrels and the occasional stray pet. But they are timid and don’t like to be around people.

data.text: I once had an Ontario Trifecta Day: I was riding solo on Highway 101, about a day east of Wawa, and was interrupted by a bear, blocked by a wolf, and startled by a moose. (I was off the bike, picking blueberries, when the bear came up behind me. No one in recorded history has ever mounted a touring bike faster.)
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: Not in London usually, no.

data.text: When I cycle in grizzly country I’m always a little worried.

data.text: ME TOO !!!
data.author: Steve Bustamante

data.text: I met a mountain biker from Alaska out riding one day and he told me he never went anywhere up there on his bike without a 10 mm pistol on him at all times, he had one of those small air horns he said would scare the Grizzlies most of the time he said they were very predictable......it's the black bears he didn't like he said they were very unpredictable hence the pistol. He said ANYTHING that smells toothpaste, tampons, food, soap, goes in a unscented bag that you hang AWAY from your camp and cook your dinner somewhere else before you get to where you're going to camp. Bears to him were like Meh no big deal, very interesting conversation learned a lot.
data.author: Steve Bustamante

data.text: I have friends that have toured Alaska with nothing more than bear spray. I have friends that live their that won’t step into the woods without a gun. I’m not going to carry a gun on a bike tour. I’ll carry bear spray and hope my karma is good
data.author: Dom Romer

data.text: Hey Dom I'm no expert on bear behavior just sharing a conversation I had with a fellow cyclist who lived in Alaska that I met in Golden Co. he was a die hard mountain biker, don't know if he was a bike tourer or not. He was very matter of fact when it came to dealing with bears is all, he carried an air horn, bear spray and a 10 mm. Was listening more about the things he did before camping, up to being at his camp, the preparations he did before going to bed more so than what, when, or why he carried a pistol. Would I wear one in Alaska ?? Yes I would because it's better to have one and not need it than the other way around......really not a big believer in karma.
data.author: Steve Bustamante
